title: MPSM V2 Extruder (Outdated See Decription)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WK8 Extruder

MPSM V2 Extruder Replacement.

This is outdated, please use the improved WK9 Extruder

This is an upgraded extruder meant to work with the V2 stock hardware (mid 2017 - Current). The only exception for parts is the Bowden tube fitting. Part of the reason to upgrade is that the stock Bowden tube fitting isn't a standard part, so when it breaks you'll need an alternative. This extruder is meant to work with a PC4-M6 Bowden Tube Fitting and an M6 nut. You can pick up a PC4-M6 fitting online easily and you should be able to find an M6 nut at your local hardware store.

Stock parts:

  • Screws
  • Arm Bushing
  • Spring
  • Bearing (4x11x4)
  • Feeder Gear

Needed parts:

  • PC4-M6 Pneumatic Straight Fitting, for 4mm OD tubing.
  • M6x1.0 Nut

Notes:

  • I printed this with PLA (Hatchbox - Pantone Yellow C), 2.1mm wall thickness (6 shells), 20% infill, no supports, no raft.

  • If you just want to print a replacement Arm, you won't need any extra parts. Just print the Arm and Cap.

  • The Extruder Cap (which holds the bearing in place) comes in 4 different tolerances, I
    recommend using whichever fits in the tightest, as it helps properly support the bearing. I used the .05mm tolerance version, and it snapped securely in place. You'll want to flip this part over in your slicer (top down)

  • The Extruder base has a 4mm hole leading up to the slot that takes the M6 nut. This is meant so you can put a small length of PTFE tubing (<20mm), cut with a V shaped point (when looking from above), so that it nestles in between the drive gear and bearing (without touching). This helps guide the filament through the extruder and will allow you to print flexible filaments like TPU.

Acknowledgements:
Shout out to robin7331 and his MPSM Extruder Baseplate V1 for the idea to make a slot for a nut to work with a PC4-M6 fitting.

title: Ding dong - singular algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Ding dong, a singular algebraic surface of degree four. This is the set of real points for which 

x^2 +y^2 +z^3 - z^2 = 0.

Has a single singularity, a bounded blob, and an unbounded skirt!

I have provided these files:

  • dingdong_thickened_smooth_fixed.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed, and is thickened for printing.
  • blocky_fixed_2.stl -- the blocky version, good for printing. 2, because 2.
  • dingdong_raw_smooth.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. Hence, the surface was thickened in Blender, before being passed through Microsoft's 3D Builder to fix internal geometry. The raw versions are not directly suitable for 3d printing. Infinitely thin, ran through sampler with fairly tight tolerances.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

This surface was sampled before I implemented cyclenumber > 1 sampling, so the surface is undersampled near critical points and singularities.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

These surfaces are generally challenging to print. Rotate, and use careful support. I use Simplify3D for the manual support placement feature. These surfaces are also very tiny in scale (arbitrary units and math and all) so require significant upsizing.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

Yes

Supports:

Yes

description.text:
I use 20" box fans for supplemental air cleaning in my shop. This is a common practice, but the way to attach the filters differs greatly. I wanted something that would attach to the fan using the existing screws and would be small/print quickly.

This was relatively quick to design and print. You can check out the actual Fusion 360 file at http://a360.co/2BAdHhv or review the STEP file attached.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.35mm with a 0.6mm Nozzle

Infill:

30%+

Notes:

I wanted this to print fast, so I selected a larger layer height with a larger nozzle using old, unnamed PLA @ 220° C with a 60° C bed. My infill was very low as there were very few infill layers at .35mm layer height. If you were using a finer pitch, I'd recommend 30% or greater infill.

Using Cura I rotated the piece to lay flat on its back (rotated 90° and used the "Lay Flat" function.) If your slicer doesn't have that function, you can rotated by 95.36°

The part was designed in Fusion 360 (http://a360.co/2BAdHhv). I used a parameters for many of the settings, so feel free to open it up and see how changing the parameters changes the design.

I sketched the base first, including the screw hole and counter sink. I extruded the base portion to {baseThickness}, leaving only the rear that was eventually lofted untouched.

Based on the original Sketch plane, I created an offset plane that was offset by {baseThickness}*2 + {filterThickness}. I started a sketch and projected most of the base sketch pieces onto it. I made some additions that would allow the standard to slant inwards. From there I lofted the rear of the base up to what will end up the top of the retaining piece. I then extruded the rest of the retaining piece down by {baseThickness}, allowing the rear surface to remain flat.

From there I applied a gratuitous number of fillets.

title: Eistute -- singular algebraic surface
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Eistute, a singular algebraic surface of degree six. This is the set of real points for which 

(x^2+y^2)^3-4*x^2*y^2*(z^2+1) = 0.

Has a singular line -- the z-axis! When you compute points on it, you get them 16 times!

I have provided these files:

  • Eistute_thickened_Smooth_repaired.stl -- has the normal vectors fixed, and is thickened for printing.
  • eistute_raw_correct.stl -- raw triangulation coming from Bertini_real. Since the program works in arbitrary dimensions, I make no effort to control normals from it -- they don't exist for 4- and higher-dimensional surfaces, but instead a tangent space which is not immediately useful for 3d printing. Hence, the surface was thickened in Blender, before being passed through Microsoft's 3D Builder to fix internal geometry. The raw versions are not directly suitable for 3d printing.
  • eistute_raw_smooth.stl -- infinitely thin, ran through sampler with fairly tight tolerances.
  • input -- the Bertini_real input file used to compute it.

This surface was sampled before I implemented cyclenumber > 1 sampling, so the surface is undersampled near critical points and singularities.

Computed with a Numerical Algebraic Geometry program I wrote, called Bertini_real and printed as part of my long-term project to reproduce Herwig Hauser's gallery of algebraic surface ray-traces in my own gallery of 3d prints. The ACM ToMS algorithm number is 976; the major published paper is DOI 10.1145/3056528 with several others preceding. Bertini_real implements the implicit function theorem for algebraic surfaces and curves in any (reasonable) number of variables.

These surfaces are generally challenging to print. Rotate, and use careful support. I use Simplify3D for the manual support placement feature. These surfaces are also very tiny in scale (arbitrary units and math and all) so require significant upsizing.

See also, my Thingiverse collection of algebraic surfaces.

Motor mount for a NEMA 23 motor onto a C-Beam Linear Actuator kit from Open Builds. I thought that the aluminum spacers and 55mm screw seemed a little flimsy, so I beefed up the motor mount and gave it a slick new look. I reused 4 of the 6 screws from the original build instructions, and replaced 2 of the 20mm with 30mm.

Appears to work great, testing begins tomorrow!

Attachment instructions

Uses 2 M5x30mm screws in place of 2 of the M5x20mm that are used to attach the C-Beam end plate to the extrusion. Remaining 2 screw holes are for the M5x55 screws that would have been used for the aluminum 40mm spacers. 1 remaining M5 screw and nut hold the last motor mount screw in place on the front of the machine.

I needed to attach the coupler to the threaded rod before sliding the mount into place, as I didn't have access to the set screw to tighten the rod.

Here is a complete quad design that I have done. The quad has very wide arms and is ideal for mounting a gimbal and camera. It also maintains the X layout for perfect stability and has a diagonal motor to motor size of 560mm making it more stable in windy flights. The top is designed to be sleek and aerodynamic for fast forward flying. I have included a gimbal mount that fits between the front arms and on my quad does not suffer from jello even though it is hard mounted. I designed the chassis to easily hold a 20c 4S 5000mah battery for long flight times, and there is also room infront of the battery to mount fpv video tx and telemetry radio between the battery and the gimbal mount. Here is a video of mine flying FPV. http://youtu.be/gogIP8V3nAY I have included two chassis designs. One is for arms with M3 holes and the other is for arms with M2.5 holes. There is also a flight controller mount that I use the blue anti vibration mounts from hobby king and also add 10 - 20gram of weight to the bottom of the controller mount for extra damping effect. The body has blocks that you can mount it to the chassis with velcro. The body was a bit of a cow to print but it did come out fine with no raft or supports. There were quate a few strands that I had to clean up on the inside that had dropped through but at you can see, the outside is fine and strong enough. I have also included some landing legs that are a tight push fit onto the chassis between the arm pillars. I would recommend a pinch bolt through the leg mounts to hold them firmly. You will have to drill the holes for the pinch bolts once on the chassis. There is also a gimbal controller board case for you to mount your gimbal controller to the underside of the quad. Hope you all enjoy.
Please post pictures if you make one. If you like this thing then please join and vote for it here. http://3dprintboard.com/showthread.php?2212-Thingiverse-Contest-3-11-17-Voting-Underway-til-March-24-(Prizes-for-Votes!)/page22 It is number #213 in the list.

I do not use rafts or supports for any of these parts. Arm mounting holes should be tapped with an M3 tap.
Gimbal mounting holes are also ready for M3 tap and also gimbal controller mounting board holes. If you prefer you can use self tapping screws but that is your choice. Make sure you clean your printing bed well with acetone. This will really help hold the parts to the bed and help prevent curling. Also make sure print bed to extruder gap is set correctly.

This was a really simple and quick project inspired by my local Japanese dollar store. They had packets of the kind of plastic "grass" that is sometimes found underneath wasabi or pickled ginger in sushi restaurants.

That seemed to be just about the perfect size for creating tall grass for figures to hide out in, but it wouldn't stand up on its own, so I designed a stand to keep sections of it vertical.

Once you've printed out the stand, stick a piece of the plastic grass into the gaps and trim any excess. Then, add a drop of superglue to each of the places where the grass meets the stand and let it work itself in via capillary action.

The kids asked for a Lego surfboard, so I said give me a few minutes. After making one that looked more like an ironing board than a surfboard.  I just resized a sketchup component and put my studs on.

Basically because its a small piece you wanna print it fast enough so that you don't need a raft. Make sure it sticks well when it prints.
In this case, the number of shells is more important than the infill percentage. Infill should be enough to add just enough structure support so that the walls of the piece do not buckle.
Rather than deal with tolerance adjustments prior to printing, I used a triangular filing tool to enlarge the hexagonal hole.

Installation Instructions

I use this to protect my car doors from bumping into a nearby wall when I open them wrong.
Installation:

  1. Cut a piece of insulation tape a bit shorter than the device
  2. Wrap both sides of the door where you want to place the device
  3. Push the device over the insulation tape ...all the way on
    The tape should keep the paint underneath it safe and multiple layers can be applied to make the device fit tighter

A WIP for a jig insert that works on T-slot tracks. In this case going off of measurements for 1010, but it seems that it's close or scalable to 2020 as well? It should be a fairly close to complete version. Should go together with various small bolt or screws along with washers. T-slot nut not included, but there are variants of that elsewhere on Thingiverse. Keep in mind that thumbwheel is meant to hold a nut, and the anchor going into the T-slot should be a small bolt or similar fastener which faces outwards. Will leave as WIP status as this may need some other adjustments. Comment feedback is appreciated and may be used in regards to improving this design.

BTW, this was inspired by this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2709797 - however that uses its own particular rail setup. This one is with the intent of using a currently common off-the-shelf railing and being adjustable.

Kept the old base model in here, since it may be useful for remixing. Doesn't have the extended support stuff attached to it.

I set about designing this Dual fang after printing a few others out and one thing i realised is they all share one thing(or the ones i printed did), they all attach using the hot end screws.
my design does not, it attaches directly to the hot end backplate using the original mounting holes for the metal cover that came on the printer, and hooks around the side.
This way i have been able to attach the fans and the fangs without touching the hot end at all, Fans are the stock fans 40mm

all you need is one of the original screws from the casing and one that is twice as long that screws in from the back, i got that one from a odds n ends box i have, not sure of the size but easy enough to get.
ive printed a few out and tweeked the design, think iv,e pretty much got it but please let me know if you come across somthing i missed, the clip has been left a snug fit on purpose but can be opened with a bit of sandpaper if needed, depends on your printer i suppose.

description.text:
This is a remix of speakboylese's Bulbasaur Coin Bank. There were two changes; the first was to make the coin slot & plug hole wider to accept Australian 50c coins, and the second was to improve the plug design to be a twist plug with a notch to hold it in place.

I printed it using Slic3r Prusa edition on my Tevo Tornado, using 0.1mm layer height for the first 10mm (to give the accuracy for the plug notches) and then 0.3mm for the rest (not necessary, but I did it for the speed) with 5% infill. Although I designed the plug to have 0.2mm tolerance, I found the result was a bit too tight at standard dimensions, so I scaled it to 98% in X & Y dimensions (100% in Z) and that worked very well; there's a chamfer at the bottom which means it can handle being scaled like that. I've left the dimensions of the STL as default in case it prints better on other machines.

description.text:
Check the new thing I made, it's improved version of this and customizable, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1411131 Fits for prusa i3 aluminium frame. No other parts required, just print and snap them on.
I tested them with 17h marathon print, worked just like I imagined they would. Even up to 190mm+ printing height. The spool actually can turn in the holder, so it will turn a bit towards to the extruder, when it goes from side to side. Especially handy when printing near the max height.

there's some options to tune in .scad -file, but the stl files should be ok too...
You may have to use some force when installing the holders, like tapping with a hammer to get the frame fully in the "hook".
.

title: [K] Support de sac poubelle (Trash bag holder)

description.text:
English translation further down.

Fixation d'un sac poubelle sur un chariot de sondage

Cette aide technique permet de maintenir un sac poubelle ouvert sur le côté d'un chariot de sondage urinaire. Il facilite l'accès du patient et des aide-soignants au sac poubelle pour y jeter les emballages liés au sondage urinaire. Le sac est fixé en accrochant ses lanières sur les tiges prévues sur les côtés.

Il s'imprime en deux parties qui s'imbriquent l'une dans l'autre.

Créée au RehabLab du CMRRF de Kerpape (Bretagne, France), avec l'aide d'ergothérapeutes.
Plus d'informations sur le site.

Trash bag fixing on a catheter trolley

This Thing is a technical aid created at the CMRRF de Kerpape (France). It aims to hang a trash bag beside the catheter trolley. Thanks to this, the patient and auxiliary nurses can throw urinary catheter wraps more easily.

The STL consists of two parts which interlock.

Designed with the help of occupational therapists, at the RehabLab. More information on this website.

author: RehabLab-Kerpape

title: Rod End Cap
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I built a laundry closet and wanted to integrate a portable laundry basket system I was using to separate colours (yes I do that).

The portable system used very thin rods and had a mesh underneath to prevent the cloth bags from sagging; something that wasn't an option for this design as I intended to pull it out, like a drawer, for easy access.
This design uses thicker rods (13mm ID/16mm OD) that shouldn't bend under a heavy load (local Bunnings Hardware Store). The end cap allows you to slip on/attach rods to the drawer slide.

Additional info

End cap thread: M5 (incl. the 12 & 12.5mm ID versions).
M3 holes through the centre of the end cap to secure the rod (optional)
Drawer slide: side mounting - zinc plated - 125kg non-locking (I go through a lot of clothes :P)

E3DV6 Clone, extruder cooling mount with adjustable part cooling ring.

Prints in 4 parts.

Parts needed:
1x M3 x 8-12mm (adjustable cooling ring)

title: Titan Extruder housing with spring tentioner

description.text:
I liked the idea of a more stable housing for the titan extruder, because especially the cover tends to bend when you put some pressure on the spring.

I found the housing designed by Kyle, but i didn´t find solution for getting an adjustable tention on the spring, so i added a M3 spring tentioner to the housing.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

60%

Notes:

Meanwhile, this is a lot of text for this thing, but i wanted to get rid of all issues i got with my titans, as i think it´s a very good extruder once everything is working as expected. Below you will find some parts for this housing, which will make things easier for you, as everything is remixed to fit Kyle´s housing. The only thing missing would be a perfectly working printed idler arm, if you tested a arm successfully, please let me know.

I removed everything about 3mm filament as testing was not successful, please only use this with 1.75mm filament.

Material: PETG, ABS, PCABS, PC, PLA (i wouldn´t recommend it, but if you got some experience with setting up steppers and could keep yours below 40°C, give it a shot if you only got PLA)

Infill: depends on the material used, but i would suggest to use at least 60%, if you are not sure about the strenght of your material, better use 80+

For the spring tentioner you will need:
1x M3 25mm screw
2x M3 nut
1x M3 spacer

Clean all holes, for the tentioner use a left rotating drill, which will melt the plastic and give you a smooth finish. The M3 screw needs to move into the hole freely.

Put the M3 screw into the base, put the 1st M3 nut on, let the screw pull it down to the buttom, pay attention that a "/\" is up, as there is a hole for the M3 nut down there, melt the nut into the plastic with a soldering iron, just as much, that the nut builds a flat surface with the plastic, wait for the plastic to harden. Screw the screw back in, mount the 2nd nut with some loctide, be sure to leave some space between the 2nd nut and the end of the screw (i used like 1.5-2mm), to have some space for the spacer and a bit to get into the spring, add the spacer, add the spring. Depending on your sprinng, you maybe don´t need the spacer. All parts used are standard sized parts, so the spacer should be able to move smoothly into the "spring hole", as well as the original spring.

At this point you can build the housing, like the original one, use the cover of the original project, as there was no need to change it.

Update Dec 21: 1.75mm filament works fine, for some filaments you may need more pressure, then the setup with the 20mm screw can provide, so i changed the part list to a 25mm screw.

Update Dec 30: 1.75 worked perfectly for me for >150h printing time

Notes Jan 06: I reuilded 3 Titans now and each one is different (different idler arm, height, filament path piece), so i will go for printed parts only (except of the gears and idler arm), as none of the originals really fit my needs and i don´t like to mess around with non equal parts like those:

idler arm: 2 got problems with flex filament during retracts (curls just above the gear)
filament path: 1 is too small for a PTFE tube to pass through
housing: heights differs, so the filament path may fit ... or not
hobbed bolt concave/straight (just to be mention that the steps/mm may vary)

Notes Jan 11: 1.75 testing is definetly finished, i just finished a >30h print without any issues, the overall printing time for one extruder is >250h with different filaments without any issues.

So here we go for a build without a original titan:

For a 1.75 extruder you will need the gears, a idler arm, a 10mm pneufit, 2 pcs MR95 bearings and those printed parts:

printed filament path (4mm ptfe tube, so for 1.75 in most cases) adapted for the housing:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2748228
There are 3 versions to match the outer diameter of different PTFE tubes.

printed adapter to pneufit (as the e3d PTFE mount never really worked for me, i´m already using them):
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2084627

Keep an eye on buying pneufits which allow the PTFE tube to pass trough, as the "printed filemant path" above, allows the tube to pass up to the extruder wheel, so you dismiss the issue of stuck filament during filament change (due to the space between the filament path and the pneufits (no matter if it´s E3D or others)).

// removed link to a printed idler arm, as it didn´t work as expected (i often change filaments (PLA, ABS, PCABS, PETG, flex ....) so for me it would only be acceptable if it works with all of them and if it got a chance to work for a long period (>1000h printing time))

author: jamesrenlund

description.text:
This Perlin Noise procedural texture has been rendered into a volume data cube. It is a non-tiling 8-bit texture at 256 x 256 x 256 voxel resolution. Iso-surface meshes are also provided in PLY and STL. These textures are from an archive I made nearly a decade ago, by simply sweeping a plane through a procedural texture and rendering out the results. Here are the available formats:
RAW data 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 16MB uncompressed
BMP sequence 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 17MB uncompressed
PNG codec AVI 256x256x256
PLY isosurface mesh 3.7M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 990K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:
engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

Model has 3 ventilation slits, a hole for reaching the reset button and 2 holes for screws on the bottom part.

The top part holds by friction and you can turn the DHT22 in every position.

Be sure to put your ESP8266 in sleep oder deepsleep mode. Otherwise it could became warm and gives you a little off temperatur readings from DHT22.

description.text:
This is a replacement for a broken battery container for Bort BAS-36 3.6v. Ni-CD electric screwdriver.
This thing is a work-in-progress, some parts will be improved in future.

And there are some extra parts for a simple charger body and dummy battery.

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V1

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed parts need to have very good layer bonding, otherwise they'll break when inserting batteries or when putting them into screwdriver.
I'd recommend printing in PET-G, or something else with good layer adhesion, or possibly something slightly flexible (SBS).

To make a new battery, you'll need:

  1. 3x Ni-CD 4/5 sub-c Ni-CD batteries with tabs
  2. printed "battery_container" and "battery_cap" parts
  3. some wires (optional)
  4. a bit of thin nickel strip to make contacts
  5. simple soldering skills
  6. extra precautions to not short out the batteries and to make sure they won't get shorted or damaged when pushed into the container or during use.

title: snap on device for DS4 + Titan Two

description.text:
Beeing a happy user of the Titan Two device by ConsoleTuner I always wanted some more buttons on the DS4 controller to use them to trigger special actions in scripts (like combos/adjustments/..) and unleash the full power of the Titan Two.

Finally, here is a fully working version of my very own snap on device for the DS4 controller of the PS4. (The video is showing the first working design, the wires at the back of the oled are now hidden plus some other small modifications):

It features a teensy 3.2 board with a 0.96" oled (i2c) display and 15 additional buttons,
3 around each analog-stick and 4 on the backside to be triggered by flexing/stretching the middle finger (I only use the index fingers for the front buttons L1/L2 R1/R2) and 5 around the oled display.

Each button can be configured to output as a joystick button/dpad-direction or a keyboard press (a-Z,0-9,Esc,F1-F12) on the fly (without the need of a pc or changing the teensy software), it supports 4 profiles.
My device uses a second usb connection in addtition to the connection from the DS4 controller to the Titan Two. It gets treated as a multi HID device and I can now create scripts to react on keyboard and/or joystick input send from my device.
The layout of the backside buttons still allows the use of modded controllers with additional buttons.

PLA and PETG works fine. Everything with 30% infill and 0.2mm layer height.

Printer:

Anycubic Acrylic I3

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Required parts:
  • A Titan Two - https://www.consoletuner.com/products/titan-two/ (it may work with gimx or via pc and maxaim plugin with Titan One too, but I haven't tested this)
  • the 3d printed parts (print them yourself or get them printed via a local store)
  • 5 tactile switches for the buttons around the oled screen "SMD 3x6x2.5 mm"
  • 10 tactile switches for the other buttons "micro pustbuttons 6 x 6 x 5 mm"
  • 0.96" 128x64 IIC I2C SPI OLED Display Module (I2C Version!)
  • flexible wires 0,04mm² or 0,14mm² -- thiner = easier assembly
  • Teensy 3.2 https://www.pjrc.com/store/teensy32.html
  • some small screws 2x10 , I cut them to length individualy where required
  • one M3x25mm screw and M3 nut
  • some glue to fixate the button around the oled
Assembly - quick overview:
  • compile teensy32_source_keyboard_joystick_display_012_release1.zip & load it onto the teensy
  • assemble the 3d printed parts with screws (except the covers and don't connect the oled casing to the main casing), shorten the screws where needed
  • place the Teensy 3.2 into its box for getting a feel for the required length of the wires
  • cut the wires to the required length plus add some length as you need to move them a bit around when you put them in their place
  • solder the wires to the teensy, switches, oled, connect everything as I have (to the same pins) or you may need to modify the code for the teensy, take a look at the pdf files:
    Snap-On Pin Usage - Pin Usage.pdf
    Snap-On Pin Usage - Button Wiring.pdf
  • push the printed buttons onto the switches, slide/put the switches into place
  • assemble the covers
  • test everything
  • have fun with scripts/scripting/titan two - gaming
More detailed assembly instructions:

Read the _assembly instructions.pdf file for more informations.

title: Screw in power switch housing and mounting bracket

description.text:
This is a box for my power switch (with screw holes) which I designed to be screwed to the leg of an Ikea lack table. I have an Anet A8 and wanted a power switch to be available near the front of my work area, whilst hiding the PSU under the table.

This housing accommodates a screw-in power switch (non rectangle) approx 49mm x 58mm (inner rect is 27mm x 46mm).

The power box fixes to the box using some self-tapping pan-head M3 screws.

To fit the mounting bracket accurately, insert some short M3 screws where the tip is just pointing out, then slot into the housing. Find the desired location, and press firmly against the surface. This will mark the screw locations. Drill out with a 1-2mm bit, and fix with at least M3x10 pan-head or longer.

description.text:
This Smoke procedural texture has been rendered into a volume data cube. It is a non-tiling 8-bit texture at 256 x 256 x 256 voxel resolution. Iso-surface meshes are also provided in PLY and STL. I have also included PNG codec AVI versions, one of which "fades" at the edges (for making surface that don't end abruptly). These textures are from an archive I made nearly a decade ago, by simply sweeping a plane through a procedural texture and rendering out the results. Here are the available formats:
RAW data 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 16MB uncompressed

description.text:

The wood one only used one piece and grabbed the side of the phone.
One of my beta testers asked to make two which worked well with a small tablet too.
I added the pins and holes just for keeping them together in your purse or pocket.
I need to tweak it a little(open the slots) to work with the thicker Otter brand cases.
It's fairly easy to import it into TinkerCad and open the slot.
The pins are a little tight at first, but after a few times together and apart they loosen up.

I included the first attempt model that is thicker and has no pins or holes.
It works well on some phones, but you have to get the slot width just right.

Keep on Printing!

title: NeoDue Part 1 - Duet Wifi for GRR Neo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Since my Neo did benefit a lot from Thingiverse (special thanks to Kakadu for his E3D upgrade and his table stiffener, and for stueckl for his inductive Z endstop); I wanted to give something back, so here is part one of my "NeoDue" upgrade, where I have replaced the old Printrboard with a Duet Wifi (and a display, but that is part 2).

To change the electronics board, you need

  • a Duet Wifi board
  • one of each of the three 3D parts printed out on your Neo
  • two M3 x 20 mm (or longer) screws to mount the board holder to the fan outlet
  • two M3 nuts to mount the fan again
  • five Ø2.9...3 mm x 6mm screws for plastic (for the cover part and the Duet Wifi)

Hints for mounting:

  • remove board cooling fan and old Printrboard electronics
  • change the cable paths as shown in the pictures (you will need to make the wires of the Z motor, the Z sensor and the main power cable ca. 10 cm longer; the others do fit)
  • turn the extruder motor as shown in the picture so that the connector faces up
  • assemble board holder (halter_leiterplatte.stl), faceplate (blende.stl) and cover piece (schutzhaube.stl) using the short screws
  • if you like to add some extra safety against oil dripping onto the board whenever you oil your linear bearings, use some tape to cover the gap between the board holder and the cover piece.
  • now mount the assembly to the fan outlet hole using the two M3 screws.
  • mount fan onto protruding screws on backside of fan outlet hole and secure with M3 nuts. Caution: blowing direction = towards z axis, i.e. the opposite direction as before! The ribs on the board holder will direct the airflow so that the steppers get the cooling they need. Works fine on my machine so far.
  • cutout left plastic cover of Neo to fit the faceplate
  • now mount board
  • don't forget to secure the wires again

For setting up of the board please refer to Duet documentation - just some short remarks:

  • I run the Duet with 19.5V as the original (I did change however the power supply to a 230W one when I changed the print head, so I cannot guarantee if the original Neo supply will provide the power needed)
  • the connectors of the steppers and the endstops can be left as they are; but you might want to switch to an NPN endstop if you currently use the inductive endstop from stueckl. (A PNP endstop requires quite a bit of additional electronics: first, you need to add a separate voltage stabilizer for the sensor, e.g. for 9V. Then add a 2,2k resistor between Duet Z endstop input pin and ground pin, and add a second resistor between sensor output and Duet Z endstop input pin, thus creating a voltage divider which needs to provide 3V at the endstop input pin if the sensor is active. The resistance of that second resistor needs to be calculated accordingly. An NPN sensor is much easier to connect, just add a BAT43 diode as mentioned in the Duet Wiki.)
  • the steppers work fine on my machine if I let them run with 500...600mA.

Printer:

GRR Neo

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,15 mm

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Print "Schutzhaube.stl" with a brim to avoid loosening during print.
Print the board holder "halter_leiterplatte.stl" with supports beneath bridges enabled if it comes loose. The faceplace "blende.stl" might also benefit from supports beneath bridges.

The board holder piece is designed to allow up to 2.5mm height of silencing material on the Neo (as shown on the pictures) which is highly recommendable on this rather noisy printer to reduce vibration of the case. If you don't have these, you may simply leave the supports in place.

description.text:
Update: Learned a bit more about Fusion 360, and I've added a chamfer to the bolt end to make it easier to thread. Download "Hub male v2" for the new version.

In preparing to build my filament dry box, I wanted an adapter for the spools to put them on a dowel or rod. Some of the other ideas I've seen involve threaded rods and jam nuts. I decided to create a self-contained hub.

The threaded design will accommodate hub widths from 45 cm to 65 cm (you can stretch this to 68 cm for the Hatchbox hubs), and with hole diameters from 45 cm to 59 cm. Designed for a central axle of up to 13 mm (1/2-inch).

This is the very first object I have designed from scratch. I've been using other things uploaded to thingiverse, and decided it was time to give back to the community.

description.text:
Added a hole in the middle to put the pin back in, that area needs to be thinner if you want to us the pin clip. I didn't bother as the pin is held in via the circuit board and friction.
Added a mounting hold to the back so it can be used with this thing, https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2516411

Should work with most Microsoft VX-xxxx models that had that rubber boot leg thing.

To take it apart,

  1. pop the silver ring off, its just glued on
  2. Unscrew the 2 screws you see next and remove that cover
  3. Unscrew the next 3 screws you see and remove the outer cover
  4. Remove the next 3 screws on the circuit board and remove the board carefully
  5. Pull the clip holding the original mount on and remove the pin
  6. Do it all in reverse after installing the printed mount

description.text:
Nothing says Christmas like crawling around Nakatomi Plaza on Christmas Eve!
I saw this pinted object on a fb post and I hunted the links. I looked and delved and it was nowhere to be found so I decided to make one. I was contacted by the original maker with the corrected links. The original can be found here: https://www.myminifactory.com/object/die-hard-christmas-ornament-52908 I'd like to recognize Daniel Beek and his amazing creativity

I did this for the memes, not the politics.

The trump head was borrowed.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1024632
CHEVY DEC

This is a simple puzzle design I remember from my childhood.
The three pieces slide together to form a circular disc. See this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zrF1JjCRyI4.
To separate the pieces again, you can insert a pencil or something similar into the center hole and turn the disc counterclockwise: it will fall apart immediately!

The model is fully parameterized, see the included OpenSCAD file.
For me a horizontal part separation of 0.5 mm worked best; 0.3 mm resulted in very tight fitting parts.

I printed this flat on the printbed, with full supports. I set the Z-distance to 0.10 mm in Slic3r to get a nicer (flatter) bottom surface.

description.text:
I love this model but it was not really printable. So I cut it up, added pins for aligning parts, and rotated everything to make it easy to print. You will need supports for the hands and head, but everything else should print without support. The parts are cut assuming your printer has a tolerance of .2mm (my calibrated ANET A8 should be .2). I did not setup print layouts because you know your printer best. And if you want/need the full assembled 3d model, go see the original that I remixed from. It really is a beautiful model. Completed model stands about 5in tall.

Update (12-23-17):
I'm assembling my second 50% scale print of this and so far I've noticed that the .2mm tolerance does not scale well. Also, the legs and the torso need some kind of alignment pin. I dunno how I am going to do that yet.

This Cellular Chips (Voronoi) procedural texture has been rendered into a volume data cube. It is a non-tiling 8-bit texture at 256 x 256 x 256 voxel resolution. Iso-surface meshes are also provided in PLY and STL. These textures are from an archive I made nearly a decade ago, by simply sweeping a plane through a procedural texture and rendering out the results. Here are the available formats:
RAW data 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 16MB uncompressed
BMP sequence 256x256x256 8-bit (zipped), 17MB uncompressed
PNG codec AVI 256x256x256
PLY isosurface mesh 0.9M polygons
STL isosurface mesh (reduced) 430K polygons

This is from my series of volumetric objects created to help people explore the differences between polygonal and volumetric representations of objects.
Learn more about the benefits of volume-based data structures for 3D printing here:
40westdesigns.com/blog/?p=371
Read more on the subject in my post on Engineering.com here:
engineering.com/3DPrinting/3DPrintingArticles/ArticleID/4523/2012-The-Beginning-of-the-End-for-Polygons.aspx

This is a simple Yin Yang ornament I modeled. It consists of two interlocking pieces. Not much more to it.

First and foremost: Print with the topmost layers set to a concentric infill. Just trust me on this one. The slicer I used created this neat pattern that you might be able to see in the black half of the ornament.

On the backs of the pieces, there are two circular cavities. These were intended for some small inserts to make the ornament double-sided, but the pieces are too small and did not work. Feel free to leave them empty, or try to fill them as you see fit.

description.text:
We needed a small shelf to hold a Samson QH4 headphone amp and two headphones to use in our recording studio. Made this in Sketchup and printed on a Makerbot Replicator+. Printed vertically with the mounting side down on the build plate and supports for the wings. Needed "helper disks" on the corners to prevent warping, my first print failed because of it which caused it separated from the build plate 3/4 the way done. Please note that you'll need a right angle 1/4" plug for the mixer because there isn't enough clearance for a normal plug.

title: Recessed vibration absorber for Prusa I3 mk2

description.text:
An ultra low profile recessed vibration damper / silencer foot for Prusa I3 mk2 or others, designed to fit in an IKEA Lack table without raising the printer more than about 1.5 mm.

This is not just a springy foot that allows the printer to shake without shaking the table, it's a real shock absorber. The shock absorbing function comes from filling the cups with fine sand (clean and dry). The sand adds some weight to the feet, and effectively transforms the energy in the vibrations to heat through friction in the sand instead of storing the energy in the spring and giving it back to the printer frame. At least that's the idea... :-)

But really, the idea was to make an ultra low profile silencer foot, since I'm building an IKEA Lack enclusure and I didn't want to raise the upper table, which works only as long as the printers is not raised either. The sand is just because I got the idea and couldn't resist trying it out. So far it seems to work as planned, but it could very well work good enough without the sand also...

I added some thin cloth between the cup and the lid to make sure that no dust from the sand escapes and starts to wear away the bearings. The sand should be washed anyway (and thoroughly dried).

The original display mount on the prusa got in the way for the lid on the front feet, so there are two stl files, left and right, for the prusa front feet that have a cutout to make room for the display. If you have moved the display (or have another printer), the round back lid can be used for all four feet.

The springs fit the lid only when mounted in exactly the same way as in the transparent drawing, except for the front left foot, where the lid is simply mirrored from the right one and because of that the springs has to be mounted 90 degrees turned... You probably need to trim the edges in the square holes and also the tips of the springs with a knife to be able to mount the lids.

The feet can naturally also be used without recessing them into the printer platform.

This is part of my take on the IKEA Lack printer enclosure thing, more will follow.

Printer:

Prusa I3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

All parts need to be rotated for printing without support, the cup-lids for the prusa front feet with openings for the display mount still needs a bit of support. I printed the springs with 5 perimeters. Everything in ABS, but pla is probably fine.

description.text:
Tetrahedral Spikey: Each side of the big triangle is about 86mm. A raft would be necessary for printing; support is not needed.

Starting with an equilateral triangle, one can extrude at a tapering angle of -19.4712 degrees (arccos(1/3) -90 ) for a tetrahedron, and then continue to extrude in the same way each central triangle (1/4 of the initial triangle) on the four faces. This is a simple and meaningful design project for inviting students to explore the world of 3D design. Of course, a touch of trigonometry would be useful, too.

Warning: The spikey can be dangerous for small children. Please consider flexible filament when possible.

References:

  1. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tetrahedron
  2. http://mathworld.wolfram.com/Spikey.html

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15-.2mm

Infill:

0 to 10%

Notes:

Trying stop printing at a percentage between 50% and 90% at 0% infill, see what happens.

title: NeoDue Part 2 - 5" PanelDue Display for GRR Neo
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Part 2 of the NeoDue upgrade - a 5" display case that fits onto the Neo (and can be printed on it despite its print size limitations).

You need:

  • one of each parts
  • 7x 3 mm x 14 mm plastic screws (four for the display, three for assembling the base pieces together)
  • 1x 3 mm x 6 mm plastic screw for the adapter board of the display
  • 4x 3 mm x 8 mm plastic screws for mounting the display onto the base
  • 2x M4 x 20...30 mm screws for mounting the complete display onto the Neo (i used some leftovers from Ikea with a large head). Preferrably you might want cut the thread for these screws ont the Neo metal base, otherwise you will need two M4 nuts to scure the screws.

Additionally you will need a drill for the holes (screws and cable) in the printer itself.

Prio to assembly:

  • try to assemble the parts, slightly sand the connecting geometries if needed.
  • surface finish all parts as you like
  • remove adapter board from touchscreen

Assembly:

  • assemble display frame and display by using the two connector rods and the four 14mm screws. Take care you place the connector rods correctly.
  • place base parts onto Neo printer and check if they fit correctly. The connection surfaces are partially cut out so that they can easily be sanded down one mm were needed to accomodate for manufacturing tolerances of the frame. Both pieces should fit snugly over their whole contact surface (visible from the sides).
  • assemble both base parts by screwing them together with the remaining 14mm screws. Carefully align them in this process.
  • check the correct seating on the Neo frame once more, slide the base to the left until it touches the left wall of the Neo case.
  • with the base seated, mark the holes for the M4 screws and the holes for the wire. The hole for the wire facing the display should be rather on the right side of the cable channel to enable the sliding movement needed for seating.
  • drill the holes, cut the M4 thread, very carefully remove any burrs and sharp edges from the cable holes.
  • assemble base part and display and secure with the four 8mm screws
  • guide cable through holes in Neo base, slide display into place and secure with M4 screws.
  • plug cable into your Duet electronics and enjoy your upgraded 3D printer with Wifi and display :-)

The hole nearby the "E" of the Neo logo in the display frame can be used to push the "Erase" button of the display. The hole inside the Duet Logo can be used to reset the display if needed. The USB port for updating the display firmware is accessible from the side.

Printer:

GRR Neo

Resolution:

0,15 mm

Infill:

50%

Notes:
  • a flat printing bed is needed (I use a glass plate)
  • all connections are designed to tolerate max. 0.1mm of dimensional error. If your printer does not achieve this, you might need to file the parts to fit.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/16KtsIno2Kw

edgar barreiro
7th grade
Didn't print my dice tower with the floor so I made one. Fits this thing: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:751718

Nautilus gears based on logarithmic spirals. The gear profiles were generated using this Maple script for which full credit goes to the original author:
http://www.maplesoft.com/applications/view.aspx?SID=95483&view=html&L=G Rendered animation of the gears: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dtkEyZwuwH4 Don't own a 3D printer? Now available for purchase at Shapeways (http://shpws.me/Kdit) The design will always stay free and open. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vTMVMf_3fCw I'm not going to upload the SolidWorks file because it is frankly a mess of different experimentation, but I uploaded the DXF which should be easy enough to modify with most CAD software. Update: No more breaking pins! I've replaced the pins with a simple press fit design. Print two of the Connector Bar v2 or the Curved Connector Bar v2 (same idea, just curved for aesthetics) and snap them together! On a well calibrated printer they should snap together easily and hold tightly with friction. If they aren't sticking together just add a drop of glue! Warning, these bars are one time use, they will be very hard to pull apart without breaking the pin. I will keep the original bars on for reference.

Print two gears and two connector bars.
Place the gears onto a connector bar, make sure the gears align as in the pictures, snap in the second bar and enjoy.

author: skellep193

title: Clips for IKEA Dioder LED strips - Ultimaker

description.text:
Simple and effective clips to mount three of the four Dioder IKEA LED strips inside the left, right and front frame of your Ultimaker 1. The clips do just that: clip to the frame and clip to the strips - no drilling, no bolts. The strips are angled for best illumination.  
There are two different clips: one larger one (left) goes in the front as this LED strip needs to fit inside the frame. The other clip takes care of left and right strips. (Actually, the side strips just barely don't fit inside the frame opening; I cut 1 mm off the little plug that connects the strip, just short of the contacts. Now it fits.)  
Easiest to put the side clips on the LED strip first, slide up to frame from bottom, clip over top. For front, snap clips to frame first, snap in LED strip. Snug fit, won't go anywhere. Just as easy to remove.

I looked at some of the clips and figured this would be a nice little project - my Ultimaker is one week old. Tried for minimalistic, hassle-free design - no holes to drill, no bolts, no loose ends.   
Drew the profile in Sketchup and initially extruded to 10mmm, but these are 8mm which is plenty. First version I forgot to tell Cura to print top & bottom - looks kind of cool tho. Then adjusted LED angle some, rounded corners and put in some cutouts to save print time.  
Shortened LED connector by 1-2 mm with a metal blade jigsaw so it fits inside the side frame openings. Front strip is inside because the strip is too long to fit in the frame opening.  
Hacked the IKEA plug and took out the transformer thingy, hot glued it into bottom along with the little distributor. (I don't know enough about electronics to mess with Ultimaker's power supply.) Mounted a switchable power jack near the other inputs. Shortened cables (they were loooong) and ran them down the sleeves.  
Printed with 20% fill density - plenty. First run I printed with brim but didn't need it.

description.text:
After trying several cable chains, none quite did what I wanted, so I designed my own albeit heavily influenced by others here. I extended my Y axis beyond the original printer, so there's some overhang, and the bottom of the extrusion is acessible, so the termination bolts there. The guide brackets support the chain in the overhang, and low profile bolts mean that it would clear a surface big enough to hold the whole printer.

The intent is that they can be printed and used without any cleanup, and that seems to have worked.

The f3d files are included so they can be remixed without having to fiddle with the STLs.

At first, please pay attention, the FC have to be installed in the right way! Tail of the Frame has small notch for the powercable, so you can see what is front and back. If you don't do it in the right way the FC board is not right in the middle of the Frame!

This is a self designed true X frame for the Graupner Alpha 110 FPV Copter. It's 110mm diagonal from motor to motor. It is flying better then the original Graupner Frame, very agile and you can fly more agressive maneuvers :) With some tuning motors it will be very exciting! The lipo tkes place on the bottom.

description.text: Simple RPI Zero Mount in AM8 Part Style
A simple round eggcup

This is a powered 2" receiver hitch back up system. When the car is put in reverse, the 9 LED's light up bright white. This can alternately be used with red LED's as a brake light system. The print is 3 pieces plus hardware and electronics.
If you are wiring for reverse lights, please get a professional to do the wiring- there needs to be a dedicated pair of wires run inside the vehicle for the reverse. (unless you have 6 or 7 pin harness on the vehicle.) You also need to have a disconnect between this design and the vehicle. If you are using as a brake system, you can use your 4 plug harness for towing.

You will need to print hitch arm 2x and base plate 1x

Parts:
-3 piece print
(4) 3mm nutserts (alternately you can use ABS and acetone fuse the pieces together)
(9) LED's with resistors 220 ohm for 12v ( this calc will check proper resistor value http://led.linear1.org/1led.wiz)
-wires and disconnects as needed

There are a total of 9 white LED's (sold in pack of 50) which can be found with resistors here: https://www.amazon.com/50pcs-Ultra-Bright-Diodes-Light-White/dp/B01MYYUS2R/ref=sr_1_5?ie=UTF8&qid=1513792429&sr=8-5&keywords=led+diode+5mm+with+resistor

Printed with PETG

special instructions

For reverse backup systems to work, there needs to be power taps going into the reverse light system. If you have a newer high end car like a BMW or Mercedes, this may not work due to the PWM controls on the light systems in the vehicles. Some cars already use LEDs for reverse lights so there is no need for resistors. Please test all circuits with proper test equiptment prior to any work. I hooked these lights up to a 10 year old car with no fancy control systems. If you have a 6 or 7 pin hitch connector, you can plug directly into that.

print_settings.Notes:: Note that the "huge" and the "long" FRBs do not appear in Thingiview; they're in binary STL format, and while they print fine, Thingiview can't cope. The "huge" one is pictured against the Whirlpool Galaxy in one of the photos.

description.text:
Fast Radio Bursts are millisecond-long radio flashes of unknown physical origin. One such, FRB121102 (named based on the day it was first detected), has been observed to repeat: from time to time there will be an hour or two in which many bursts are detected. These bursts are not simple flashes: they appear to consist of sub-bursts that drift downwards in frequency. This thing is a collection of 3D prints of the burst structures, visualizing this structure by printing it out in plastic.

Each of these models is to the same physical scale: the height of each point is proportional to the flux density, and the time axis is marked in milliseconds, while the frequency axis is marked in hundreds of megahertz. The time of the first tick is marked on each object, as is the frequency range, the date, and the instrument used: PUPPI (Puerto-rican Ultimate Pulsar Processing Instrument), at the 300-m dish at the Arecibo Observatory.

This thing includes models for a number of individual bursts. They are named according to the date and time of their detection, but I have also added a word to the filename to briefly describe what the burst looks like.

For more information on this object and this data, see the note at ASTRON's web page or the paper Michili et al. 2018 and Hessels et al. 2018.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15 mm layer height

Notes:

The only overhangs are the slightly indented text; this should pose no difficulty to the printer. The STL files are huge, and the gcode files are also large, but the shapes are not very difficult to print. The main challenge I had was getting them off the print bed when they were done.

The tallest of these is actually just barely short enough to be printed on a Prusa i3 Mk2s - in fact PrusaControl will refuse to slice it, and though slic3r will slice it fine, there is a risk the print head will collide with the spool holder.

Note that the "huge" and the "long" FRBs do not appear in Thingiview; they're in binary STL format, and while they print fine, Thingiview can't cope. The "huge" one is pictured against the Whirlpool Galaxy in one of the photos.

We have raw data files containing burst flux as a function of time and frequency. I load these into an ipython notebook and use a Savitzky-Golay filter to smooth them. I then use SolidPython to add annotations and create OpenSCAD files. I render these files to STL on a compute server as OpenSCAD requires quite a lot of RAM for this computation.

remixed_from.author: wildBill83
remixed_from.title: wildBill's PG35L Direct Drive Extruder V1.1

title: ORDbot PG35L Extruder & X Carriage
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is an extruder/X-carriage set designed for the ORDbot.  It is based off of WildBill's extruder body.
It has low weight and keeps the mass close to the extrusion to reduce vibration and enable faster movement.

WARNING: THE FREE END OF THE MOTOR OUTPUT SHAFT MUST BE SUPPORTED BY A BEARING. IF THIS IS NOT DONE THE GEARBOX MAY FAIL. My fix was to drill a 1/2" hole in the far side of the extruder body and hot-glue a bearing in. This seems to work well enough to prevent any issues. Attached are the following files:
  • ORDbot_PG35LExtruder.STEP :: STEP file of entire assembly as seen in the picture.
  • ORDbot_PG35LExtruder.zip :: Packed SolidWorks assembly, version 2009.
  • WheelPlate.STL :: STL file of X carriage.
  • WB_Extruder_IdlerArm.STL :: Extruder idler arm
  • WB_Extruder_Mainbody_R1.STL :: Extruder body.
  • Assembled_Frontview.JPG :: Picture of physical assembly showing zip tie routing and general details.
  • Assembled_Rearview.JPG :: Picture of physical assembly showing zip tie head location and extruder body mount bolts.
    • I strongly recommend printing the carriage in PLA. I tried ABS and it is not stiff enough. I designed a belt clamp piece but it didn't work out. I resorted to a M3 screw with an M4 washer and just clamped the belt between the washer and clamp block. This works fine and doesn't rub on the extrusion. The belt clamp block may rub on the extrusion, file it down if it does. It's a little too tall and I didn't redesign it. The extruder body should be printed in ABS, both pieces can be printed at once. Since Slic3r can make its own plates now I didn't bother. NOTE: The extruder is set up to take a J-head hot-end, mounted with metal squash plate with 2 M4 bolts set 15mm from the CL of the extruder. The extruder is mounted with 4 M4 bolts, one of which uses a blind nut trap. This bolt needs to be cut to length so it doesn't bottom out in the hole. The belt should be run through the slots in the side ribs. The eccentric space should go on the bottom wheel. This way most of the load is carried on the top 2 wheels, which are much more stiffly mounted since the standoffs are integrated into the plate. The motor should be zip-tied to the plate using the slots above and below (see picture). This helps reduce oscillations of the motor. I got lazy and just hot glued the fans to the carriage instead of making fancy brackets. The motor runs hot and requires a 40mm cooling fan. The motor can be found here: http://store.trinitylabs.com/trinitylabs-micro-extruder-gearhead-motor-and-options/

comments.text: I'm running with your carriage plate, grafting it onto a shaft-driven (by an off-carriage geared stepper,) quad extruder for the Hadron.  I don't see a limit switch in your photos, nor holes for one on the carriage.  Did you move your x-axis limit switch to the gantry?

comments.text: Yep, limit switch is mounted to the extrusion by the X motor.  I saw no point in putting the end stop switch on the carriage - all that does is require you to deal with an additional 2 wires that move around.

description.text:
I found a Klipsch ProMedia THX 2.1 amplified speaker system at a second hand store ($15). One of the grills was missing. So.....

Note: This speaker system has a serious design flaw. One of the speakers was cutting out. The left/right speaker connections (mono 3.5 mm jacks) are prone to causing intermittent connections. No wonder these systems are showing up in second hand stores!

There is an easy fix - open the speakers (4 screws in grille pin sockets), disconnect the spade wiring connectors, forcefully rip out the sucky jack from inside with heavy duty pliers, and solder in a length of speaker wire to the blades where the spades were (observe polarity). Thread the new wiring through the hole where the jack was, and tie a knot (inside the cabinet) to eliminate stress on the solder connections. There was no stress relief in the original flawed design.

The system now sounds better than new.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

100

Notes:
  • Support structures are built in - turn off all supports in slicer.
  • Use a 2mm brim (or more).
  • I printed 2 of these in PLA on the same build plate - worked well - orient so that the front sides face outward. Allow the brims to merge for better stability.
  • Use external fans if printing in PLA to reduce warping.
  • The support structures are hollow - even when using 100% infill (recommended)

• Cut the supports near the middle, and gently rotate off the pins.
  • IF NEEDED, wrap the mounting pins in electrical tape for firmer (and rattle free) fit.
With calipers, 123D Design and about a dozen hours of futzing.

title: Charging dock for Nintendo Switch Pro Controller

description.text:
Tired of scratching up the top surface of your Nintendo Switch Pro Controller while plugging in the USB type-C connector? Wish it didn't take 2 hands to plug it in? Don't like seeing the ugly cord sticking out while the controller sits there charging? If so, this is for you!

I designed this dock to have a place to set down and display my Nintendo Switch Pro Controller while it charges. When paired with the recommended power cord and magnetic dongle (link below), the Pro connector charges while docked. It features a simple one-handed operation. You just set down the controller and you are good-to-go. Removal is also a snap with one hand as well.

Magnetic charge cable optional: Wsken Magnetic 6.6FT/2M Type-C Cable
Link: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B077FLBMX3/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

Some assembly required. 3D-print the main dock and both of the wire holders. Clamp the holders together over the power cord (leave some extra cord length to align with the dock opening) and insert into the bottom of the main dock. Screw holes are provided if needed although mine press-fit together nicely.

For those interested in using the original scan data of the controller, here's a link:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2765943

Additional notes about my plans for the next revision:

  • This is my first revision of the design. I'm planning to develop Rev 2 soon.
  • The styling of the stand's outer walls is bland. If there are any industrial designers who would like to send me some idea renderings / sketches, I'd consider your design direction.
  • I'd also like to incorporate the Nintendo Switch logo on the front face.
  • Also, I'd like to add a feature that allows the charging LED on the controller to be visible.

comments.text: Hi Mikey.  I started with a 3D scan of the Pro Controller, then brought the stl data into NX 11 as a faceted body.  From there, I was able to resurface the underside of the controller using the faceted body’s nodes (best fit surfs).  I was able to join the new surfaces into a sewn sheet body that I could use to trim out the pocket for the controller to sit in (with a 0.5mm offset for clearance).  The rest was using NX 11’s modeling tools to construct the structure of the cord holder and surfacing around the outside.

So I found a rotational casting machine here on thingiverse that seemed easy enough. Here is the link to it: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1473325. The main problem I ran into was that the only real instructions were that "assembly should be self explanatory." This was not the case. Assembly really was not self explanatory. Issues with piece not going together well, to issues with the belt not being tight enough or slipping a great deal. I have made a few alterations to the design so it should work fairly well now.

Side plates for the Armattan Chameleon with a hole pattern that fits the Foxeer Arrow Cam and/or similar sized 3 hole cams.

The cam has been lowered slightly to provide better clearance between the GoPro strap and the top of the camera.

Allows for more tilt than anyone would ever use.

There are left and right pieces, because the section that mounts the cam is thicker to give it more strength.

Print with 100% infill.

*Note: I have been flying with these myself and they have held up in a nasty crash which bent the aluminum cam brace and broke the battery plate AND main frame!

title: Team Fortress 2 Pyro Axe (TF2) repaired and split

description.text:
I got my hands on the Pyro figure from notamusician, however it seemed to be direct from the game. I did some auto repairs and then split the figure up into four sections. This removes a ton of supports that were needed for the tanks on his back. I then split the tanks in half so I could print them without supports as well.

As you will see in a pic I posted, I manually added a few extra supports for his feet and some in his hands. They came off easily and overall it printed a lot cleaner than expected.

The axe can be printed in one part but it needed supports to keep it up so I split it in half.

I printed the body at like 50% infill but that was just so it could be put up near a lit background without the honeycomb effect showing through. It could easily print at 10% even. I did 0.08mm layer height just for the detail.

This is my first time learning how to cut up models so if I did something wrong please tell me!!

remixed_from.title: Garmin Edge Stem-Cap Mount for 1-1/8 and 1.25 (Giant Overdrive).

description.text:
This is a replacement Garmin mount for the XLAB Kompact series triathlon water bottle:
https://xlab-usa.com/torpedo-kompact-500.html

I have my bottle mounted back on my bars, with the bottle cage reversed to fit well and keep the weight closer to my steerer tube, however that means I have to tilt my head and look nearly straight down to see my Garmin cycling computer using the included mount.

This replaces that mount, extending it out further in front to see it more easily at a glance. Simply unscrew the existing mount and replace it with this. I have not tested it with the water bottle facing forwards, it may be tricky removing/inserting your water bottle in that case.

Included are two sizes, a 6 inch (end to end) extension, and a 5 inch. The 5 inch is pictured made. Leave a comment if you'd like a different length, as that's quick to change.

title: webcam tower camera mount m6 raspberry pi controlled

description.text:
just a different camera mount with a M6 screw.

I will also upload my files here to control the Webcam Tower with the Raspberry Pi GPIO Pins.
Works great in use with the Octoprint-Server on the Pi. The only problem with the Octoprint Server is it can't start a script.

You have to get the Gcode to System plugin and the Custom Control Plugin to use it.

Notes for the .sh files

Change the PIN numbers to your used ones. You have to change the numbers in the define.sh file and in the motor1.sh (A = IN1, B = IN2, C = IN3, D = IN4) and in the motor2.sh (A = IN1, B = IN2, C = IN3, D = IN4).
Motors will have a certain direction. right.sh and left.sh will use the file motor1.sh.
up.sh and down.sh will use the file motor2.sh
If it turns the wrong way, just rename the files to the correct direction.

It's not possible to move the motors just by 1 step, that's because I would need a function to know which step was the last one and also even 8 steps are so less movement I just don't need it.

Usage:
just run the scripts up.sh, down.sh, right.sh, left.sh.
Example in an ssh client: /home/pi/webcam/up.sh 5

EDIT:
If you use it with the Octoprint Gcode System Commands, look at the last picture.
The Symbol "&" at the end starts the movement without interrupting the print.
Just don't press the button again before the movement ends, it shortcuts the circuit of the motor and stepper-driver. Which leads to overheating of the motors or destroys them.

I may not assume any liability if something bad happens. Be safe and sure about the things you do.

/home/pi/webcam/ musst be the full directory where you saved the files.
up.sh is for the up movement.
5 is the number of steps *8 to let the motor make.

EDIT2:

The Script "define.sh" should be changed to your pins, and be in the autostart so you won't get any problems with bad pins.

If someone wants to write a better script for more precious adjustments feel free to make it, would be great if you would upload it here(and please use the remix button) or send it to me directly, I will upload it here.

Feel free to ask for help if you need some. My english is not the best, sorry.
[email protected]

author: funbart

description.text:
V 2

Just got to print it, solder up the parts, configure, bind, test fly it. I think its the final version. I plan on printing this in PETG like how I did the one in picture #4. I fixed all the red markings (parts that needed improvement).

Special Build Notes:
Drill 2 holes in the side motor mounts where the red dot is in picture #3. Through the side of the frame as well. Do this on both sides to make holes to mount that piece to the frame with a nylon spacer in the middle. I didn't trust my printer to do this accurately enough for the holes to line up. The side motor mounts may need filing a bit, as did all the mounting holes in my first test fit print.

Concept Notes:
This is my experimental brushless micro drone design. It is a stretched plus configuration, but I made the props on different levels. Stepped? That's what I think that should be called if it doesn't already have a name. Is that ok for flight? I saw that on a quad x design, I bought a frame from ebay like that recently. Haven't tested either yet!
One of the main goals of this build is to not have the propellers in the view, as well as to do something different that looks cool, and might be easier for me to tell which way its facing when flying it "freestyle?" Without the FPV feature. (I Plan on having the camera attached with a small plug so I can unplug it to save battery power if not using the FPV.

Parts List: (Note I bought a parts kit from Aliexpress. Search for "brushless micro drone kit". I put a picture of what the parts look like. Planning to design my own propeller guards for whenever any of these break.)

4* JMT 1103 7800kv Mini Brushless Motors

1* 2" 2.5" Propellers Guard Bumper Props Protector (Green or Blue)

1* 2 Pairs 2035 Propeller 2.0 inch 50.8mm PC Props 5-Blade CW CCW Paddle (Green or Blue)

1* Q25 MINI VTX+CAMERA 25mw 16ch Transmitter 800tvl coms Camera
(Tested this, major drop outs with my cheap usb receiver. Will most likely use a better one.)

1* PIKO Mini BLX F3 Flight Control Tower 4 in 1 BLheIS 10A 2~3s ESC

Nylon or metal standoffs 30mm x 8. (16 bolts/screws for such). One thing nice about the parts kit, it had more than enough mounting hardware to design my frame thicknesses around.

New in this version: Finalized the mounting idea for the side motor mounts. Hope it is secure enough. I imagine 2 holes on each side might be stronger, but I'm going to test with one first to save on the weight of another nylon spacer and two more screws.

Even though I did a great deal of research about this I am still guessing on some stuff. What angle do quadcopters even fly at while moving forward? Is it 45? Note: A focus of this design was to get the propellers out of the view and still have the camera pointing straight ahead? I do plan on making the camera mount adjustable.

Printer update: Got my Maker Select V2 running again. Put in mosfet mod, added swiss micro all metal hotend. Printing this pretty good so far considering I am using the cheapest of pla filaments Actually, it was printing terrible, but when I started using a raft it now works better than ever. Go figure.

Hobby Update:
Been flying my first quadcopter. Its a "Toad 85mm Brushless" variety with a 2s battery, some store bought prop guards, and a small FPV camera. Its a Quad X variety. I'm not a great pilot at all yet, and even suspect that things need to be balanced better, and or setup better in Betaflight. I crash almost always. I have landed safe a couple of times, but more of plop downs than really smooth landings. Thank goodness for the soft turf at my mothers back yard of 3 acres. Got stuck in a tree twice. Once a broom was enough, the other time I hit the throttle and it came out. Thank goodness.

Peace, and happy safe printing and flying!
